snippet.textOriginal: After putting it on the back burner for 5 years; I beat the damn game.

snippet.textDisplay:
The main reason this game is harder from the other souls games is because of the main mechanics itself. Unlike the other souls games where you put points into attributes, different weapons, and it‚Äôs your build determining a key to your success, Sekiro just doesn‚Äôt have that. It‚Äôs One weapon, some side utilities, but it‚Äôs 1 weapon and getting REALLY good with that. It‚Äôs skill tree based adding moves you can combo together. 

On top of aggression play, in souls games where you dodge roll and hit, of course there‚Äôs more than that but that‚Äôs just the basics, In Sekiro you have to be in your enemies face and not run away putting pressure how well can you hold your opponent. You cannot pause or move away because ‚ÄúHesitation is Defeat‚Äù. I always compared to a Devil May Cry or Metal Gear Revengance where it‚Äôs not about how well is your build, but how well are *YOU* at playing your given instrument that is the gameplay. The better the flow of combos, fast paced reaction, and timing, the better the solo. I always liked that about Sekiro. 

It doesn‚Äôt tell me my build isn‚Äôt good enough, but I‚Äôm not good enough, until I am
snippet.textOriginal:
The main reason this game is harder from the other souls games is because of the main mechanics itself. Unlike the other souls games where you put points into attributes, different weapons, and it‚Äôs your build determining a key to your success, Sekiro just doesn‚Äôt have that. It‚Äôs One weapon, some side utilities, but it‚Äôs 1 weapon and getting REALLY good with that. It‚Äôs skill tree based adding moves you can combo together. 

On top of aggression play, in souls games where you dodge roll and hit, of course there‚Äôs more than that but that‚Äôs just the basics, In Sekiro you have to be in your enemies face and not run away putting pressure how well can you hold your opponent. You cannot pause or move away because ‚ÄúHesitation is Defeat‚Äù. I always compared to a Devil May Cry or Metal Gear Revengance where it‚Äôs not about how well is your build, but how well are *YOU* at playing your given instrument that is the gameplay. The better the flow of combos, fast paced reaction, and timing, the better the solo. I always liked that about Sekiro. 

It doesn‚Äôt tell me my build isn‚Äôt good enough, but I‚Äôm not good enough, until I am

snippet.textDisplay:
I finally beat Sword Saint after a few years of playing this game.

It's great... though there are a few design choices I'd like to see changed. 
1: refilling your resurrection power. All of your resurrection pips should refill upon resting. Requiring the player to grind out some kills because they used a resurrection is tedium for no reason.
2: Multi phase bosses with no check points. The game wants you to practice and learn move sets but requires you to play through bosses and phases that you've already beaten. I get that it's to limit your resources (firecrackers are really good and having them for each phase of a boss would trivialize the game), but this seems an issue with the over-utility of the Shinobi tools that the devs solved by making bosses tedious to practice.

A better solution would have been to have a second type of checkpoint where you start the particular boss or phase with the same resources you came in with and can choose to restart the encounter or awaken at the idol.

Another solution would be to have any boss encountered open to be challenged from the idol. Some sort of Meditations on Victory. You could practice a particular boss or mini boss via the idol and then challenge the boss for real.
snippet.textOriginal:
I finally beat Sword Saint after a few years of playing this game.

It's great... though there are a few design choices I'd like to see changed. 
1: refilling your resurrection power. All of your resurrection pips should refill upon resting. Requiring the player to grind out some kills because they used a resurrection is tedium for no reason.
2: Multi phase bosses with no check points. The game wants you to practice and learn move sets but requires you to play through bosses and phases that you've already beaten. I get that it's to limit your resources (firecrackers are really good and having them for each phase of a boss would trivialize the game), but this seems an issue with the over-utility of the Shinobi tools that the devs solved by making bosses tedious to practice.

A better solution would have been to have a second type of checkpoint where you start the particular boss or phase with the same resources you came in with and can choose to restart the encounter or awaken at the idol.

Another solution would be to have any boss encountered open to be challenged from the idol. Some sort of Meditations on Victory. You could practice a particular boss or mini boss via the idol and then challenge the boss for real.

snippet.textOriginal: I've played and beaten elden ring, lies of P, demon souls, and stellar blade.. this is next.

snippet.textDisplay: Finished the game today and oh man... this combat system is unmatched. The level of satisfaction of winning a fight, especially the bosses, is just unreal. Overall, Elden Ring is still my favourite but Sekiro is so so close. It's easily one of the best games ever made. I understand it's not for everyone, as it requires a lot of patience to master the combat system. But once you learn it, there's nothing quite like it.
snippet.textOriginal: Finished the game today and oh man... this combat system is unmatched. The level of satisfaction of winning a fight, especially the bosses, is just unreal. Overall, Elden Ring is still my favourite but Sekiro is so so close. It's easily one of the best games ever made. I understand it's not for everyone, as it requires a lot of patience to master the combat system. But once you learn it, there's nothing quite like it.
